image.altText: Philip Lowe giving evidence, resting his head on his hand.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank leaves interest rates steady at 4.1 per cent for the third month in a row, but says further increases to rates may be needed to bring down inflation in line with its target.

title.children: Interest rates remain on hold as Philip Lowe calls time on his seven-year stint as RBA governor

image.altText: Plastic playground equipment in the front yard of a childcare centre, seen through a metal fence.

items.synopsis: A child dies two days after being taken to Royal Darwin Hospital in a critical condition.

title.children: Police investigating death of toddler after medical incident at Darwin childcare centre

image.altText: a man in a high-vis jacket loading cattle from a truck to a ship.

items.synopsis: Malaysia is once again accepting live cattle and buffalo exports from Australia. Will Indonesia follow suit?

title.children: Malaysia lifts suspension of live cattle and buffalo exports

image.altText: A man in a suit stands and speaks at a microphone in parliament, with other politicians seated behind him.

items.synopsis: The government's relationship with Qantas and Richard Marles's use of taxpayer-funded flights are expected to dominate Question Time.

title.children: PM fends off questions about Qantas and Qatar decision in Question Time

image.altText: A close-up of NT Chief Minister Natasha Fyles.

items.synopsis: Natasha Fyles's office has released the costings of the nine-day trip after concerns were raised about transparency around ministerial travel.

title.children: NT chief minister's nine-day US trip expected to cost more than $90k

image.altText: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce speaks to the media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Embattled Qantas boss Alan Joyce brings his retirement forward by two months after a horror period for the airline.

title.children: Alan Joyce abruptly departs Qantas after scandalous week and 'many ups and downs'

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: The judge overseeing a criminal trial into the deadly eruption of Whakaari White Island in 2019 dismisses charges against the three brothers who own the volcano, with proceedings set to continue over their company's involvement.

title.children: Judge in Whakaari White Island trial dismisses charges against brothers who own volcano

image.altText: An undated photo of Frank Foley and his son, Shaun.

items.synopsis: Human remains located by a fossicker last year have been linked to Frank Foley's close-living relatives, and police will conduct a forensic search at the site today.

title.children: Queensland police hope 'offenders can be brought to justice' after cold case breakthrough

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce will leave Qantas after 15 years with $125 million, while the airline's operations have suffered and its reputation has been trashed, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The never-ending spin that protected Alan Joyce and Qantas from reality has started to unravel

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce announces he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. The Reserve Bank keeps interest rates on hold today at 4.1 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Joyce to leave Qantas tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months, RBA leaves interest rates on hold, ASX loses ground

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Many economists think the Reserve Bank could be done with raising interest rates unless there is an inflation shock in the next quarterly Consumer Price Index figures, which are out late next month. CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson spoke to my colleague Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel. "I am in the camp that interest rates have peaked." "There would have to be something quite surprising and shocking movement in inflation from here for them to go any higher. " She sees rates on hold until next year because of high services inflation like the cost of rent and insurance. "I think the earliest we might see interest rates declining maybe mid next year and that is because the services inflation side is still too high." Ms Thompson says higher interest rates are hurting younger households in particular. "The interest rate rises have definitely hit the consumer." "Not just mortgage holders but renters as well, that younger aged cohort, 25 to 18 year-olds, and 25 to 34 year-olds who are feeling the pinch." "It is a consumer recession out there but hitting different generations at different ways." And CreditorWatch is seeing the average size of company invoices declining and trade payment defaults rising slowly. Ms Thompson says that means more businesses going under. "Which means there are certain suppliers out there and customers who cannot pay their bills on time, and when we see that data starting to rise we know that business failure rates are going to rise 6 to 12 months down the track."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economists: rates on hold

children.content: Many economists think the Reserve Bank could be done with raising interest rates unless there is an inflation shock in the next quarterly Consumer Price Index figures, which are out late next month.
CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson spoke to my colleague Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel.
"I am in the camp that interest rates have peaked."
"There would have to be something quite surprising and shocking movement in inflation from here for them to go any higher. "
She sees rates on hold until next year because of high services inflation like the cost of rent and insurance.
"I think the earliest we might see interest rates declining maybe mid next year and that is because the services inflation side is still too high."
Ms Thompson says higher interest rates are hurting younger households in particular.
"The interest rate rises have definitely hit the consumer."
"Not just mortgage holders but renters as well, that younger aged cohort, 25 to 18 year-olds, and 25 to 34 year-olds who are feeling the pinch."
"It is a consumer recession out there but hitting different generations at different ways."
And CreditorWatch is seeing the average size of company invoices declining and trade payment defaults rising slowly.
Ms Thompson says that means more businesses going under.
"Which means there are certain suppliers out there and customers who cannot pay their bills on time, and when we see that data starting to rise we know
that business failure rates are going to rise 6 to 12 months down the track."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row as expected. The central bank kept the official cash rate at 4.1 per cent today at its meeting, the last to be led by outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe. He will be replaced by the first female governor, Michele Bullock, later this month. The RBA has raised interest rates 12 times since May last year to curb inflation. Consumer prices have eased back to 4.9 per cent on an annual basis, with the RBA predicting that the cost of living could drop to 4 per cent by the end of the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA stays steady on rates at 4.1 per cent

children.content: The Reserve Bank has kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row as expected.
The central bank kept the official cash rate at 4.1 per cent today at its meeting, the last to be led by outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe.
He will be replaced by the first female governor, Michele Bullock, later this month.
The RBA has raised interest rates 12 times since May last year to curb inflation.
Consumer prices have eased back to 4.9 per cent on an annual basis, with the RBA predicting that the cost of living could drop to 4 per cent by the end of the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just 15 minutes to go. Traders are betting on a 95 per cent likelihood that official interest rates will stay on hold at 4.1 per cent. Watch live on ABC News Channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA decision coming up at 2.30pm AEST

children.content: Just 15 minutes to go.
Traders are betting on a 95
per cent likelihood that official interest rates will stay on hold at 4.1 per cent.
Watch live on ABC News Channel.

image.altText: A young boy is smiling in a red t-shirt.

items.synopsis: A Sydney court hears secret recordings in which William Tyrrell's former foster father appears to berate a child in an expletive-laden tirade as he fights charges of assault and intimidation.

title.children: Secret recordings of William Tyrrell's former foster parents played in court after house and car bugged for 12 months

image.altText: A woman lies back in a chair smiling, while someone injects her forehead with a syringe.

items.synopsis: Australia's medical regulator says it is cracking down on cosmetic procedures such as botox and fillers, but those living with the long-term impacts of botched procedures say the focus has come too late.

title.children: Cosmetic surgery crackdown now targeting fillers, botox and other procedures

image.altText: Grange Road street sign

items.synopsis: Police say it appears a 14-year-old who suffered critical injuries in an alleged abduction at Glen Huntly in Melbourne's south-east was an "innocent victim" making his way home from school.

title.children: Police investigate after 'heinous attack' leaves Melbourne schoolboy critically injured

image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: The Victorian Premier says the 12-month time frame set out by the Yoorrook Justice Commission to deliver urgent reform may be too ambitious for the government.

title.children: Daniel Andrews questions 'challenging' time frame for Yoorrook recommendations

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe, wearing earrings in the colours of the Aboriginal flag, sits in the senate, she looks up to the left

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe reveals her unlikely friendships with political adversaries, and says she was once approached by former Victorian premier Jeff Kennett to run for the Liberal Party.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe reveals her 'weird' and unlikely friendships in the Senate

image.altText: A grey tabby feral cat against a background of red dirt.

items.synopsis: A new global report is released, providing the most comprehensive assessment on biological invasions to date.

title.children: Feral cats, rabbits and fire ants driving biodiversity loss in Australia, but report finds one success story

image.altText: A man wearing a jacket and collared shirt speaks at a press event.

items.synopsis: Ben Wyatt says the repeal of the controversial legislation was inevitable after consensus among the key players broke down, but he's surprised pastoralists want to revert to the old laws.

title.children: 'Regulations went too far': Architect of WA's Aboriginal cultural heritage laws says repeal was inevitable

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: Hundreds of defence personnel and other officials have attended a military ceremony to commemorate three marines who died in the MV-22B Osprey aircraft on the Tiwi Islands, ahead of their final voyage home.

title.children: Bodies of US marines killed in Osprey crash farewelled before repatriation flight

image.altText: A man wearing a black and red polo shirt stands next to a wire fence with 'polling place' affixed to a banner.

items.synopsis: More people in the Northern Territory are on the electoral roll than ever before, but a lower percentage of them are actually voting, according to the NT Electoral Commission.

title.children: Darwin by-election shows 'significant decline' in voter turnout, sparking concerns ahead of Voice

image.altText: An aerial photo of a coal power plant surrounded by Australian bush.

items.synopsis: The NSW government will "engage with Origin Energy" on a proposed extension of the life of Australia's largest power plant.

title.children: NSW government moves to delay closure of Australia's largest coal-fired power station

image.altText: Prime Minister Kalsakau and Penny Wong sign a security agreement

items.synopsis: The new prime minister of Vanuatu flags he wants to rewrite a security pact his predecessor signed with Australia, saying parliament is unlikely to ratify the agreement in its current form.

title.children: 'We are not pro-Chinese': Australia's security pact with Vanuatu to be 'revisited' under new PM

image.altText: Dozens of photos, most arranged on top of each other, on a table

items.synopsis: Three decades after the legendary Queen frontman's death, more than 250 snaps from his personal albums are released publicly for the first time, painting a new picture of a world only his "nearest and dearest" knew until now.

title.children: Freddie Mercury's 'mythology busting' private photos revealed after 30 years

image.altText: a woman's hand holding a newborn baby's feet while in a maternity ward

items.synopsis: An upper house committee into the prevalence of birth trauma in New South Wales, expected to go for several months, received a record 4,000 submissions from the public.

title.children: 'Stop infantilising women': Birth trauma inquiry described as 'me too' moment for mothers in NSW on day one

image.altText: Man in white shirt

items.synopsis: Jurors have been told not be to be tempted to be television detectives when deliberating the fate of a man police allege gave a toddler a fatal dose of an antidepressant.

title.children: Jury hears man charged over toddler's antidepressant death 'not sharpest knife in the drawer', but not a killer

image.altText: A woman in a bright blue blazer sits at a park bench.

items.synopsis: In Tasmania's far north-west, 17 per cent of the population identifies as Aboriginal and some fear their voices will not be heard if the Voice to Parliament referendum passes.

title.children: 17pc of this community identify as Aboriginal — so why do some fear a Yes vote?

image.altText: A foreshore featuring palm trees in front of a calm, sheltered ocean on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The court heard the man, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, also assaulted two members of the public who intervened in the incident.

title.children: Man accused of attempting to drown son faces court from hospital bed

image.altText: A seven-month-old boy with scratches on his face and head.

items.synopsis: Seven-month-old Jack had been left alone, unsupervised, in a room when he was beaten by another child. His mother is now pursuing legal action and lawyers say their caseload of injuries sustained at childcare centres is increasing.

title.children: Injuries sustained at childcare centres are on the rise. Experts say there's one common factor

image.altText: A close-up of a man with cropped dark hair.

items.synopsis: Darryl Valroy Young, the man accused of killing three family members at a remote cattle farm last year, has appeared in court for the first time in months.

title.children: Man charged with murder over shooting deaths of three people at Bogie attempts to represent himself in court

image.altText: A dark-haired boy standing on a boardwalk in bushland. His face is blurred and he cannot be identified.

items.synopsis: The boy's devastated family has been told he is likely to spend months in hospital. A 27-year-old man has been charged over the Sunshine Coast incident.

title.children: Boy, 12, on life support after being knocked off scooter by alleged drunk driver on Father's Day

image.altText: A red illuminated Westpac bank logo on a black wall with a blurred man walking past

items.synopsis: Westpac is facing civil court proceedings from ASIC, which alleges it failed to respond to hardship requests within the time required by law.

title.children: Cars and property seized after Westpac failed to respond to hardship requests, ASIC alleges

image.altText: An Australian Electoral Commission banner tied to a fence. It says "polling place" with opening hours 8am-6pm

items.synopsis: Rather than writing numbers, ticks or crosses, voters will have to either write the word "Yes" or "No" on their referendum ballot papers.

title.children: Voting on the Voice will be different than federal elections. Here's how

image.altText: India moon lander's view of the moon from space.

items.synopsis: The Indian Space Research Organisation will now focus on a sun research mission as the nation hopes to make its name in the field of space travel.

title.children: India puts moon rover to 'sleep' after successful mission

image.altText: A lorry with a billboard of Julian Assange arrives at the front of a London court house.

items.synopsis: A multi-party delegation will visit Washington DC later this month to make the case for the US to drop extradition proceedings against Julian Assange, ahead of the prime minster's visit to the US in October.

title.children: Federal politicians to urge US to drop extradition of Julian Assange
